hints_raw: How many intervals will you have to use? Where will their endpoints be? What about their midpoints?
question: 1 (f)
sols_html:
With n = 2 and an interval of \([0,4]\) we have

\[\begin{aligned} \Delta x = \frac{4-0}{2} = 2\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} x_j = 0+j\Delta x = 2j \quad\text{for } j=0,1,2\end{aligned}\]

i.e. our subinterval endpoints are 0, 2 and 4.

To approximate with midpoints, we need to take sample points

\[\begin{aligned} x_1^* = 1 \quad\text{and}\quad x_2^* = 3\end{aligned}\]

(these are the midpoints of \(x_0\) and \(x_1\), and \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) respectively).

The area under the curve is approximated by the midpoint Riemann sum, which yields

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^4 f(x)\,dx &\approx \Delta x (f(x_1^*) + f(x_2^*)) \\ &= 2\left(\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{1}} + \frac{1}{1+\sqrt{3}}\right) \\ &= 1 + \frac{2}{1+\sqrt{3}}\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Use a Riemann sum with n = 2 and select the midpoints of subintervals to estimate the area under the graph of

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac1{1+\sqrt{x}}\end{aligned}\]

from 0 to 4.
